title: 107_hr3375
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Embassy Employee Compensation Act" and includes definitions for key terms. The Act, known as the "Embassy Employee Compensation Act," defines key terms such as claimant, collateral source, and economic loss related to compensation for individuals affected by the bombings of United States embassies in East Africa on August 7, 1998. The "Embassy Employee Compensation Act" defines terms like eligible individual, noneconomic losses, and Special Master for compensation under applicable State law. The 11th Victim Compensation Fund of 2001 was established under the Air Transportation Safety and System Stabilization Act. The purpose of this Act is to compensate individuals injured or killed in the bombings of US embassies in East Africa on August 7, 1998. The Attorney General will administer the compensation program and allocate funds for administrative costs. SEC. 5. DETERMINATION OF ELIGIBILITY FOR COMPENSATION. The Special Master develops a claim form for filing compensation claims under the Act, ensuring it can be filed electronically. Claimants must provide information on physical harm suffered when submitting claims. The claim form for compensation under the Act requires information on physical harm suffered, economic and noneconomic losses, and collateral sources of compensation related to the bombings of United States embassies in East Africa on August 7, 1998. No claim can be filed without this information. The Special Master will review and determine eligibility, extent of harm, and compensation for claims filed under the Act within 2 years of promulgated regulations. The Special Master will review and determine eligibility, extent of harm, and compensation for claims filed under the Act within 2 years of promulgated regulations. The Special Master shall not consider negligence or any other theory of liability when making a determination on a claim. Within 120 days of filing a claim, the Special Master will complete a review, make a final determination, and notify the claimant. The claimant has the right to be represented by an attorney and present evidence during the review process. The Special Master determines compensation for claims under the Act, including the right to present evidence and witnesses. Punitive damages are not included, and compensation may be reduced by collateral source compensation. Eligibility is determined for claimants under specific criteria. The Special Master determines compensation for claims under the Act, including the right to present evidence and witnesses. Eligibility for claimants is based on specific criteria, such as being a U.S. citizen present at the U.S. Embassies in Nairobi or Dar es Salaam during the bombings in East Africa on August 7, 1998, and suffering physical harm or death as a result. The Act allows for one claim per individual or deceased individual's personal representative, waiving the right to file a civil action for damages from the bombings of U.S. embassies in East Africa. The Act allows for one claim per individual or deceased individual's personal representative, waiving the right to file a civil action for damages from the bombings of U.S. embassies in East Africa. Individuals involved in pending civil actions must withdraw from the action within 90 days of regulations being promulgated under section 7 to submit a claim under this Act. SEC. 6. PAYMENTS TO ELIGIBLE INDIVIDUALS. The Special Master authorizes payment to claimants under this Act within 20 days of determining compensation. This Act allows for advance budget authority for compensation payments. The Attorney General can accept contributions for funding this Act and use a separate account for payments. Prioritize using funds from accounts with funds provided before using appropriated amounts. SEC. 7. REGULATIONS.

Within 90 days of the Act's enactment, the Attorney General, in consultation with the Special Master, will establish regulations for the Act, including forms, information requirements, hearing procedures, and assistance for filing claims. 

SEC. 8. RIGHT OF SUBROGATION.

The United States retains the right of subrogation for any claims paid under this Act. Attest: JEFF TRANDAHL, Clerk.
